WRITING.TITLE: What constitutes a missed dose?
WRITING.TEXT: I just got prescribed a starting dose of lithium and Wellbutrin XL today. I #8217;ve never had to take medications daily before, the only other medication I #8217;ve been on is short release adderall, which I take whenever I need it. According to the info sheet I got for Wellbutrin, if you miss a dose, you should just skip it and take your next dose on schedule. But I #8217;m very unsure about what a missed dose is exactly; if I #8217;m scheduled to take it at 9am every morning, and I don #8217;t remember to take it until, say, 10:30am, did I miss the dose? How much wiggle room is there?

I #8217;m not a parent, so I really can #8217;t say, but I imagine that the way your child views those scars, both on you and on other people they may come across, is largely up to how you explain it to them. I think telling them the truth once they finally ask is really important, so that they can learn about it in a safe environment, from someone they love, and so that they don #8217;t form negative opinions about people who self harm, or who have mental illnesses. And, also so that in the future if they have issues like this as well (hopefully not!), they #8217;ll know you will understand. If you tell them the truth in a casual manner, and use it as a moment to teach your kid to be kind to others and especially to themselves, then I feel you wouldn #8217;t have to worry about your scars having a negative impact on them. You don #8217;t have to go in to detail, you could just describe it as a symptom of an illness you had/have. Idk. I #8217;m no expert whatsoever, but I hope maybe that helps you a little? My case was way different from what OP described (that experience sounds downright awful ): ), I admitted myself by going to a behavioral health ER where they then transferred me to an inpatient facility. I #8217;m over 18 so I could legally voluntarily admit myself, but if you #8217;re a minor, your parents can bring you and I think it still counts as voluntary commitment. Involuntary commitment is a different can of worms and I think is more like what OP described, that #8217;s when the doctors or police or whomever make the decision that you are not stable and need to be watched for your own safety, whether you want to be admitted or not. Edit; lemme add that I was not actively suicidal, I just went bc of self harm. Which is a valid reason to go as well, you don #8217;t have to be on the very brink of suicide to get help if you want it.

I can't answer all your questions, but I do have a bit of experience with using NYU mental health services. I struggle with serious depression and suicidal thoughts too, with a healthy dose of self harm on top. I'd never gotten help in my life before this semester, when I started seeing a therapist/counselor (those are the same thing) at the wellness center. I came in for a drop in session after a prof reported me, and they immediately set me up with two appointments for the following two weeks. After that, I kept seeing my therapist (Wanda Ramos is her name, she's wonderful) every two weeks, and I continued to see her regularly over zoom after the pandemic. I don't have NYU insurance, or even an insurance that covers anything outside of my home state, but I still got regular therapy for a lengthy amount of time. The limit never came, because they care more about making sure you're safe than about getting you through the system. I've only stopped seeing Wanda now because I have a new therapist at home. Maybe you've done this already, but what you should do is call the wellness hotline (or email, or securely message through the student health care portal), tell them what you're looking for, and they can help you from there. They can give you information about what they offer, whether you need certain insurance for it, AND they can also help you find something outside of NYU if thats what you need. You can give them your insurance and your location and they can find you a bunch of options that work for any of your requirements and preferences. Also, you can meet with these folks over Zoom, which I don't think costs anything internationally? So if you're cool with that, it's definitely a great option. It freaked me out at first but zoom therapy is not much different from regular therapy. I think, also, you should mention to them that you're having suicidal thoughts. That's really serious, and will probably give you some priority. I think it did for me. I honestly don't know if that helps at all, but maybe seeing the experience of someone else with really similar issues will give you an idea of what might be in store? Idk. I'm not an expert on their services at all. But I know that they saved me from probably chopping my whole arm off. If it were not for Wanda, I would still be living in secrecy, wearing long sleeves all the time, and lying to my parents. So I'm really grateful for them, even if the whole system isn't great. Regardless of it all, though, I really hope you end up getting the help you deserve. No one should have to feel that way. Please stay safe.

ok I know I #8217;m seven days late but. Vaping is not entirely bad for you, it doesn #8217;t weaken your immune system so that you wouldn #8217;t be able to fight corona. Vaping can be dangerous, yes, but those cases of serious issues come from what #8217;s IN the vape, not the act of vaping itself. Nicotine e-liquid that you can buy in a store is safe. But illegal vape cartridges, like ones with THC in them, can be dangerous because they #8217;re being sold on the black market and so there #8217;s no regulation about what goes in them, nor any way of knowing what #8217;s in them. If your partner is using e-liquid purchased from a real store, they #8217;ll be just fine! I mean, it #8217;s still something they should try to quit, but in the meantime, they #8217;ll be okay. My therapist did something similar when I brought up my self harm, and when she saw my cuts I think she decided they weren #8217;t #8220;bad enough #8221;. Two months later, I landed myself in the hospital bc it got so severe. I think it is a typical response, because the thought process there is sort of like, #8220;well, self harm is your only coping mechanism and you aren #8217;t hurting anyone else by doing it, so it #8217;s fine for now #8221; which I guess has some validity to it, but the much more pressing issue there is the fact that self harm is an addiction and will only keep getting worse. You should try bringing it up again. I #8217;m sure your therapist did not intend to dismiss you like that, and maybe if you express your concern about it a bit more than they #8217;ll see that it #8217;s a bigger problem than they thought? Don #8217;t try and tell yourself that your self harm is not a big deal, or not #8220;bad enough #8221;. You deserve to be heard about this.

The academic system is not structured well, especially not for people who struggle with mental illness. Grades don #8217;t reflect your abilities, your intelligence, your talent, or any of what makes you a good person. I know it #8217;s still stressful anyway, because whether we like it or not, grades can have an impact on our future, but I just wanna make sure you know that failing is okay. My classes are definitely majority male, but there #8217;s still a decent amount of women in the department. One thing I don #8217;t really like is having a class that #8217;s mostly men with a male teacher. Math is a hard subject so the people who pursue it are usually quite smart... and I think sometimes the men in the classroom will start to get a bit arrogant, especially when the male professor also speaks arrogantly. Idk I #8217;m probably biased but I just generally really dislike #8220;I #8217;m smarter than you #8221; attitudes in the math department and I tend to notice it a lot from my male peers. Aside from that though, I #8217;ve not been personally discriminated against! I think one of my favorite experiences in math so far was this summer camp I went to in high school. There was an equal amount of male and female students there AND of male and female professors. The aim of the program was to do high level mathematics in a really laid back, non serious way. There was no exclusionary jargon or anyone saying #8220;cmon, it #8217;s so easy! #8221; and I loved that so much. It was just pure indulgence and discovery of fascinating mathematical topics all while laughing our asses off with each other. I try to remember the beauty and joy I found in mathematics while I was there when I #8217;m starting to feel like I #8217;m not good enough for the field.

I wouldn #8217;t say I #8217;m addicted either... I think addiction is just a really complicated thing that I don #8217;t fully understand. I mean, you can technically become addicted to anything, but not all addictions are created equal. Nicotine, for instance, creates a genuine chemical dependency where your body needs it in order to function. But my body definitely doesn #8217;t need sh to function. I do often find myself self harming daily, but I think that #8217;s only because it happens to be my favorite and most effective coping mechanism. It does tend to escalate though, I have to go deeper each time to be satisfied. Perhaps that #8217;s a symptom of addiction, but I #8217;m not sure. What I can say for sure is that all of our brains are vastly different, and I imagine there are others who DO feel that their bodily functions are dependent on self harm. Idk, shit #8217;s super complicated.

I participated in a study last year that wanted to look at adolescents (I #8217;m 19) with a history of suicidal ideation/self harm and see how capable they were of remembering past events and imagining future ones. Before I went they had me list over the phone 10 positive events and 10 negative events from the past five years. When I got there, much of the experiment consisted of me either describing some of the events I listed with great detail, or being given random elements from the events I listed and trying to imagine positive or negative future scenarios that could possibly take place involving those people/places/things (I hope that made sense lol). Anyways, I found it incredibly hard to imagine future scenarios. The results of the study aren #8217;t out yet I don #8217;t think, but I wonder if being suicidal/depressed really does make it harder for you to just visualize a potential future for yourself. I sure as shit can #8217;t do it. It #8217;s all blank.
